In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

You can write the function in Julia like this:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump::Int=3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        throw(ErrorException("This function only works with DateTime types."))
    end
    
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end
```
In this code, I used `Dates` package to perform the date and time operations. This function takes a DateTime type as input (`dt::DateTime`) and an optional parameter `bump` which defaults to 3 (hours). It checks if `dt` is of Date type. If it is, it throws an exception stating that this function only works with DateTime types. Otherwise, it increases the time by `bump` hours and returns the result.
